title: The Battle for Gibeon
shortSummary: Joshua 10 recounts a pivotal military campaign in which Joshua leads Israel to a decisive victory over five Amorite kings who attack the city of Gibeon. The chapter highlights God's miraculous intervention, including the famous event where the sun and moon stand still to allow Israel more time to defeat their enemies. This chapter demonstrates God's faithfulness in fulfilling His promises and His power to fight for His people.
timeline: c. 1406 BC - The Conquest of Canaan under Joshua's leadership

keyCharacters.name: Joshua
keyCharacters.description: The leader of Israel who commands the army and faithfully follows God's instructions in the conquest of Canaan.

keyCharacters.name: Adonizedek
keyCharacters.description: King of Jerusalem who leads a coalition of Amorite kings against Gibeon in an attempt to punish them for making peace with Israel.

keyCharacters.name: The Five Amorite Kings
keyCharacters.description: Kings of Jerusalem, Hebron, Jarmuth, Lachish, and Eglon who unite to fight against Gibeon but are ultimately defeated by Israel.

keyCharacters.name: The Men of Gibeon
keyCharacters.description: Inhabitants of Gibeon who seek Joshua’s help after making peace with Israel and facing attack from the Amorite coalition.

definitions.definition: To defeat or put to rout; to cause confusion and disorder among the enemy.
A form of execution and public humiliation where the defeated kings were hung on wooden structures until evening.
An ancient Hebrew text referenced in the Bible, believed to be a record of heroic deeds and historical events.
The Israelite camp and base of operations during the conquest of Canaan, symbolizing a place of renewal and obedience.

outline.heading: The Amorite Coalition Against Gibeon
outline.description: Adonizedek, king of Jerusalem, alarmed by Gibeon's treaty with Israel, gathers four other Amorite kings to attack Gibeon, setting the stage for a major battle that tests Israel’s faith and God’s power.

outline.heading: Israel’s Divine Victory at Gibeon
outline.description: Gibeon calls on Joshua for help; God assures Joshua of victory and miraculously intervenes by causing the sun and moon to stand still, enabling Israel to defeat their enemies decisively.

outline.heading: Capture and Execution of the Five Kings
outline.description: The five Amorite kings flee and hide in a cave but are captured by Joshua’s forces, publicly humiliated, executed, and their bodies secured, demonstrating Israel’s total victory and God’s justice.

outline.heading: The Conquest of Southern Canaan
outline.description: Joshua leads Israel in a systematic conquest of key southern cities, destroying their kings and inhabitants as God delivers them, fulfilling His promise to give the land to Israel.

application: Trust God’s promises and courageously obey His commands, knowing He fights for His people as He did for Israel.
Seek God’s help urgently in times of trouble, just as the men of Gibeon called on Joshua for deliverance.
Be encouraged that God can intervene miraculously in our battles, even when circumstances seem overwhelming.
Demonstrate courage and faith in leadership roles, following Joshua’s example of boldness and reliance on God.

keyVerses.text: And the LORD said unto Joshua, Fear them not: for I have delivered them into thine hand; there shall not a man of them stand before thee.
keyVerses.significance: God’s assurance to Joshua highlights the importance of trusting in divine power rather than human strength.

keyVerses.text: And the sun stood still, and the moon stayed, until the people had avenged themselves upon their enemies. Is not this written in the book of Jasher? So the sun stood still in the midst of heaven, and hasted not to go down about a whole day.
keyVerses.significance: This miraculous event demonstrates God’s sovereign control over creation to accomplish His purposes for His people.

keyVerses.text: And Joshua said unto them, Fear not, nor be dismayed, be strong and of good courage: for thus shall the LORD do to all your enemies against whom ye fight.
keyVerses.significance: Joshua’s encouragement reminds believers to be courageous and confident in God’s victory over opposition.

keyVerses.text: And all these kings and their land did Joshua take at one time, because the LORD God of Israel fought for Israel.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores that Israel’s success was due to God’s direct intervention, not human effort alone.
